subject: Art
title: Drawing Fabric & Drapery
description: How cloth folds follow predictable patterns based on support points.

hook.text: Fabric folds look chaotic, but they follow rules. Hang a shirt from a hanger and folds radiate from the support point. Pull two corners and folds stretch between them. Logic, not chaos.

buildup.text: Seven fold types: pipe (tubular), zigzag (compressed), spiral (wrapped), half-lock (sharp direction change), diaper (hanging between two points), drop (falling from support), and inert (pooled on the ground).

discovery.text: All folds originate from support points (shoulders, elbows, knees, hangers, hooks). Identify the support points first, then draw folds radiating from them. Gravity pulls everything else down.

twist.text: Fabric material matters: silk creates soft, flowing folds with gentle curves. Denim creates stiff, angular folds. Thick wool creates few, large folds. The material type defines fold character.

climax.text: Drape a t-shirt over a chair. Identify the support points (chair back, seat edge). See how folds radiate from each point. Sketch the major fold lines â€” ignore small wrinkles.

punchline.text: Folds aren't random. They radiate from support points and gravity does the rest.

quiz.question: What determines where fabric folds originate?
options: Support points where fabric is held, hung, or stretched
